I don't understand how this would work. Wouldn't having a single player skip to day cause continuity problems? It doesn't seem possible on multiplayer. Please explain?

@RoyalRex2
One person sleep means whenever it in night only one person has to sleep to make it day instead of multiple people
Phantoms will still spawn according to when you last slept
Coordination between players will have to be done if one wants mons to spawn but that is not difficult to ask in chat

I defiantly think this needs to be added to realms and servers as an option WITHOUT activating cheats especially because afk players make it impossible to sleep

Even better: /gamerule requiredPlayerSleep 

And that let you choose how many players were required to sleep.
this is possible in 20w51a
it is?

With the new game rule,

/gamerule playersSleepingPercentage <percentage>

we can actually do this in 1.17. For example, if there are 4 players on a survival multiplayer world, if you set the `playersSleepingPercentage` to 25, then you only require one player to sleep. The same goes if you had 20 players, and then set the game rule to 60, then 12 people would be required to sleep! Does require a bit of math, but you can use a calculator for that!

Hope this helps :)

Except it's not working in Bedrock. As of v1.17.11 not working in my Realm on PS4.

 

Why not?
It would be nice to have this without cheats on

this was kind of added in 1.19 with /gamerule playersleeppercentage <value> but instead of having it where a specific number of players sleeps its a percentage where 1 is if 100 players is on a server only 1 has to sleep but if its like 1000 players 10 people got to sleep etc.
This sounds like a fun option for people who want an increased difficulty.

@MinecraftMstr01 The whole point is that it's a gamerule, so people only turn it on if they want to. Obviously I realize that not everyone will want to play this way. Would you mind deleting your comment?
Hey, pretty good idea for people who want a challenge, not the best idea but I like it.
I actually had a similar idea where your health doesn't regenerate unless you drink a potion of regeneration or healing.  I'm voting!
You should be able to change how much health is lost (e.g: You could change it to 4 health lost, etc) Otherwise, great idea!
Good idea, InsideWindows26, and thanks for the support!

@MacchuPicchu96 I actually think this is a great idea, however I do have one qualm which I would tweak. If a heart was lost each time you died, then as the game gets harder (Nether/End), you would die more as you would have less health, ultimately spiralling. Therefore, I would suggest that an option be added where no hearts were lost, but there was a death cap, so that you could only die, say, ten times before the world locked you out. That way you don't run the risk of fighting the Ender Dragon with a 2HP maximum.

 

I also think your contributions to this site as a whole, both in suggesting ideas and in providing reasonable feedback on some of the posts, and indeed on encouraging other users to think carefully about whether what they have to say is a worthwhile suggestion, are truly noble and it's appreciated that new contributors like me know there are people who will give genuine consideration to their ideas instead of just upvoting whatever has a good title or whatever their mate posted

Mr. Crawley,

I can see where you are coming from! I too think that such an option would be useful. However, I personally would find it much more fun to lose hearts after dying. That's part of the danger of it - there'd be a very real and scary penalty for dying! Better play very carefully if you want to have most of your HP to fight the dragon with ;)

Your comment about my contributions to the site as a whole is, quite frankly, wonderful to read. I really appreciate that you took the time to write it. You're more than welcome to add me on Discord if you want to keep in touch, by the way.

@MacchuPicchu96

I do like the idea of a diminishing health bar, but I think (like InsideWindows26 was saying) an option to change the health lost (which could include none) would be a good idea, allowing players to change the difficulty of their challenge.

Also I would like to add you on Discord but, being rather unfamiliar with it, I don't know how :(

Just pointing out, bedrock has the following:

/scoreboard players randomize <player> <objective> <min> <max>
This is so simple to add, and would make a lot of things for mapmakers a LOT easier.
Please add this
Would be cool, especially since it is already a thing in Bedrock edition, so the idea itself isn't an automatic no.
Yes please.. For example "/scoreboard players set @s example random[1..8]" -> Set the score example from @s to a random nuber between 1 and 8.

If you only need two values (true/false) you can use the new predicates added in 1.15.

However, I don't think this is a bad idea at all. The only way I could possibly think of that reproduces this using the current tools is using /loot to create an item with a random count, damage, or attribute modifier amount, then copying that amount to the scoreboard with /execute store ... run data get..., and then deleting the item, which would definitely work but is very clunky and inefficient.

+1 from me, except don't limit it to scoreboard values. Instead, use an all purpose command /random that would return a value between a specified min and max, so that I would work for randomizing other containers for data as well.
Not sure if you mean on java since I don't do commands on java but bedrock has had a random function on scoreboard for a good while.

How has it been over 4 years and this hasn't been added to Java? Bedrock already has it, adding it at this point would be a parity addition rather than just an addition we don't have. Mojang please!!! For 1.19.4 or 1.20!

I can follow the reasoning behind the idea, but I don't think it would be aplicable to the game.
When playing music discs in the game, the song title already gets displayed.
If you are talking about the background music there would be other problems, mainly inconsitency.
Clients could have the music muted, what would the command display when no song is playing, what if clients are overwriting the default music with a resource pack, and most importantly, the background music is client side, so running this command at the same time with multiple players would result in different outputs.
Using it in command-blocks, the server console or a command function would be impossible because all these sources do not belong to a client and therefore don't have the ability to play music.

Robin Rogge - you have some good points. I am indeed talking about the background music, the music discs would not be necessary because, as you pointed out, the song title is already displayed. In fact, maybe a better idea would be to have a similar system to the one that displays the title of music discs, except it could be toggled by gamerule and off by default.

If clients have the music muted or no song is playing, the command should do either do nothing or give an error message, maybe something like "No music is playing".

Resource packs might be a problem, but I think that if someone is trying to use the /song command to identify the background music, they probably aren't using a resource pack anyway. If someone does try to use the command while also using a resource pack, I'm sure there is a solution. Maybe the command could output the name of the song that the resource pack is overriding, maybe it could search the resource pack files for the name of the song that is currently being played (if that's possible - to be honest I'm not quite sure how resource packs work) and display that, or maybe you'd just get an error message, something like "This command does not work with resource packs".

As for command blocks and the rest, I know it is possible for commands run in command blocks to behave differently from those typed in chat. For example, the /help command, when typed in chat, displays a list of commands. But in a command block, you just get a quirky message. So I think it would be possible to make /song work differently for command blocks, server consoles and functions. I don't know what it would do - maybe it would just be an invalid command. I don't really know about functions and client-server interactions and stuff like that, but I don't think this aspect is really an issue.

Hopefully all of the above makes sense and I haven't misunderstood or overlooked anything. There's a good chance I misunderstood something, because I don't know much about the technical side of things. I just thought the command would be nice to have.

The problem would remain that it would not be unsyncable with the server.
I'm not sure about '/help' but since that can be overwritten by server plugins I'm quite sure there are no 'client commands' in minecraft. Each command is (probably) executed on the server, and the server has no information about what music is playing on each client.
The way I see it is that this idea can only be implemented in form of a client command, and to do that the entire concept of client commands would probably have to be implemented first.
A gamerule won't work either because it's also a server-side setting.

When you think about how much effort it would take to implement the functionality of this command I'm quite sure that looking up the song's name on Google is a lot quicker :D
I love this idea! If this is implemented, please let us use it without enabling cheats.
Noteblocks xD

I love watching mobs fighting each other, but the only way to get them to fight is to:

1. Build a wither,

2. Name a vindicator Johnny, or

3. Use natural hostility (such as skeletons vs wolves).

I have spawned hundreds of mobs in the hope that they fight, and while I have seen some great battles, I have only ever seen three creepers explode.  Also, I have never been able to get ghasts, guardians or drowned to fight in the battles because vindicators named Johnny and withers have a hard time attacking them.

In conclusion, I support and approve of this suggestion.
and if you added the ! like "/mobtarget Minecraft:skeleton [!Minecraft:villager]" it would attack everything except for the villager.

If this command affects natural hostilities, it might be a better idea to move that functionality away from a single command and toward datapack entity_type tags, where every hostile/neutral mob would have a tags that specify the mobs that they are naturally hostile and neutral towards. Then you could edit those entity_type tags with a datapack, which is a much more organized way of implementing the same feature.

I like this idea. I think the format would be more customizable, and fit into vanilla better if it were /mobtarget @e [type=(attacking mob type)] [type=(attacked mob type)]. Then you could also do /mobtarget @e [name=(attacking mob name given by name tag)] [name=(attacked mob name given by name tag)]. Also like someone else said you could do /mobtarget @e [type=(attacking mob type)] [type=!(excluded mob type)] to make a mob attack all mobs besides the ones you exclude. You could have command blocks set up to easily make a mob attack all mobs besides a group of different mobs.
I always wanted something like this . hope it gets added

Not quite related, but neutral mobs like zombified piglins have the AngryAt NBT tag, whereas normal piglins have the "Brain" -> "memories" -> "minecraft:angry_at" -> "value" NBT tag. Both allow to set the mob's target as long as its UUID is known. Unfortunately, there's nothing like that for regular hostile mobs. Otherwise, one could use a command like /data modify entity @e[type=zombie,limit=1,sort=nearest] AngryAt set from entity @e[type=piglin,limit=1,sort=nearest] UUID. However, one could only set a single target this way. The team functionality has so many shortcomings that can't be relied on to make epic fights between mob groups and even if teams would be fixed, using /data would still be very cumbersome. Having a straightforward way to make mobs be hostile to each other would be a great addition to custom maps.

this is a great idea

How about a more complicated version of the command. 

For instance, "/locateblock ~ ~ ~ " would allow you to find the block right where you are. If you type in the full coordinates of a location ( i.e, "/locateblock 12 34 567") , it will tell you the name of the block in that area. "/locateblock" itself would act the same as "/locateblock ~ ~ ~". 

You could also do something like this for the "/locateblock" CMD (CMD means command):

"/locateblock entities @e[type=chicken] mode"

This would locate all blocks every chicken is standing on, then find the block that comes out the most. If it is a tie, it would show you BOTH blocks and both of their IDs. And this:

"/locateblock entities @e[type=chicken] mean" 

This would locate all blocks every chicken is standing on, then find the average ID number of the blocks stood on by chickens, then give you the ID number of that block. And this:

"/locateblock entities @e[type=chicken] median"

This would locate all blocks every chicken is standing on, then find the block that has the moderate ID and give you the block and ID of that one. 

"entities" in the /locateblock CMD would mean that you want to know the blocks that an entity is standing on. 

"players" in the /locateblock CMD would do the same as for entities. 

"blocks" in the /locateblock CMD would show you the coordinates, ID, and block of something. I'm beginning to run out of space for characters, now, I'll say more on the next comment. Really love your idea and hope it gets added!

So /locateblock could be broader, being just "/locate" instead. This would be useful because then you could use these after typing "/locate" 

"biomes" 

This would locate biomes. I saw this in another post and it could be merged. 

"structures"

This would remove the previous command used for finding structures, so now if you wanted to find a structure, you'd have to use the /locate CMD. 

"find:entities", "block:entities"

Instead of just "entities", "find:entities" will locate all entities in your world and list how many there is in your world (and the coordinates of them all), and "block:entities" will do what "entities" did before. 

"near" , "far"

This ["near"] would show you how close the nearest specific block in a world to you is. The latter subcommand, "far", would show you how far a specific block in a world to you is. Both would also include block ID and coordinates. 

( Note: When I say "block ID", I'm referring to the game code's ID for the block's item.) 

"find:players" , "block:players" 

Similar to the "find:entities" and "block:entities" subcommand. 

That is all from me, again I love love love your idea.
so there isn't a plugin/mod/program to do this?

Literally, Advancements AND Loot Tables both have NBT compatibility, why not crafting too!?!?

This would add sophisticated crafting trees where crafting can acknowledge NBT tags in items for input and output items with NBT tags.

Adding this would be so much more efficient instead of having alternatives like throwing entities on the ground or revoking advancements to return a modified item.

The community has developed 4 different workarounds for this feature being missing, and none of them are good. Commandeering a special tileentity as a fake crafting bench, tossing items on the floor together, using an intermediary knowledgebook item, or go modded. All of them add significant overhead to the process that make it not feasable for near-vanilla servers to add custom items that can be crafted into other custom items, which seems to be at the heart of why one would want custom roleplay items.

We should be able to see the spawn coordinate in the NBT data

382048814612

Yep, we currently can; but with the addition of dynamic dimensions it's impossible to discern the dimension a player has their spawnpoint in. At best you can hardcode a few "known" dimensions, but if their spawnpoint is in a custom dimension datapack makers are out of luck without killing the player, thus increasing the player's deathcount (which is not wanted in this case, player shouldn't have to have a death increase for moving back to spawnpoint).
This is a very good idea! Would make it handy to teleport people away from the end, because now you have to specify a point to teleport to!

This would be very useful, although I personally think it makes more sense to add functionality to the spawnpoint command instead of adding an entirely new command. I.e. the syntax of  

spawnpoint <targets> <position>

would be changed to

spawnpoint set <targets> <position>

and you could also do

spawnpoint teleport <targets>

for the functionality you described.

I can totally agree!

Please don't forget

matches X

where X is a double. This way, you don't need a scoreboard to test for fixed numbers.

Expecially needed for storing and reading the result of a command with

/execute store success storage ...
&
/execute if data storage ...

If you try checking with the second command, it can't differentiate whether the first command failed or not! In both cases it stores a value, but that value is not checked.

Turns out, you actually can test whether the nbt data matches a pre-determined value. It's not as versatile as what you're suggesting, but at least we have a workaround for now.

You just need to use the standard nbt syntax and it will check if the data matches:

/execute if data entity @s {SelectedItem:{Count:1b}}

Which would almost work like your example:

/execute if data entity @s SelectedItem.Count matches score @s testscore
matches tag doesn't really make sense, how would the game know what kind of tag to use?

My use case is this: I want to obtain 100 Diamond Blocks and then use them to create a build that specifically will have that exact amount, I want to build it in creative and then count how many blocks I have used in that area, so that I could easily tell weather I have let's say 124 and then I could remove 24 and have build that has the exact desired amount of blocks that I need.

So for a small number of block types I figured out a way to do it with Clone

 

if you do /clone x1 y1 z1 x2 y2 z2 x3 y1 z1 filtered minecraft:BLOCK move

I previously copied the structure so I am not taking apart the original (maybe use a structure block)

but do that it will tell you how many blocks it moved successfully, you have to do this for every block type in the build but its the best Idea I came up with.

Made this instead, but I'd still like to know how to call on "pass_count".

/execute if entity @e[scores={Board=2},name="redPlayer"] run setblock ~ ~1 ~ minecraft:stone
/scoreboard objectives add Board dummy
/summon minecraft:chest_minecart ~1 ~ ~ {CustomNameVisible:0,Invulnerable:1,CustomName:"redPlayer"}
/scoreboard players set @e[name=redPlayer] Board 0
/clone ~-5 ~1 ~2 ~4 ~10 ~2 ~-5 ~1 ~-2 filtered minecraft:yellow_concrete normal
/execute store result score @e[name=redPlayer] Board if blocks ~-4 ~1 ~-2 ~5 ~10 ~-2 ~-4 ~1 ~-2 masked

That is great idea! Well thought.
Mainly because dealing with "doubles" in scoreboards is horrible...

I sorta agree with you, but ^ means xor in some programing languages like c and c#

 (im not sure about java)

and | means or, i think these should be inmplemented in both modify functions along with & for bitwise and operations and << >> for bitshift operations.

until this gets implemented I'd recommend you using 

 /execute store result score <entityname> <objectivename> run data get entity <entity with your nbt> <path to your nbt>

to dump the nbt into a scoreboard and

/execute store result entity <entity you want to store your score in> <your score> <datatype of your score> 1 run scoreboard players get <entity your score is saved in> <objectivename>

to do the opposite, then you can use scoreboard operations on the scores

This seems like a great idea, especially for working with types like longs, floats and doubles, which you can usually not do math with without losing precision.

Just a detail, but I'd make it so that the result of the operation is converted back to the type of the input, so for example adding 2 to 3.5d would result in 5.5d and adding 3.5d to 2 would result in 5. The reason for that is that types need to be consistent in lists and therefore putting a double into a list of ints would fail.

The main post lacks a few details that I thought I would like to add. I would suggest and strongly advocate for a designated realm operator to be able to download the world data. This is because with the data, the operator is able to examine data that can find who has been griefing or stealing. Essentially, the operator would not have to ask the owner for the data every time and could instead go ahead and take care of troublesome individuals on the realm. This is already possible for the owner and would be as simple as making it possible for operators one designated by the owner. This is a simple idea that could significantly help keep realms in order and keep control over disrespectful individuals. If it is still a concern for some reason that operators, (the people who take care of the realm), should not have these powers, then I would say that one could add further permissions allowing the owner to give access to the world data download, although I believe this to be unnecessary.

You can actually move the structures as well, but you'd need to move the files from the world folder.

Structures are server side, not client side; as such they cannot be cross-world.

Simply move the (world)/generated folder to the other world file, or in a data pack.
Users can save time by choosing their own location for structural save

Here's how I think cross-world structures could work.

Additional save setting: Save to World / Save to App. Allows you to choose whether the structure block saves the structure to the world file (what Minecraft normally does) or to a separate 'structures' file. Structures saved in the structure file can be loaded to any world. Additional option: Transfer From App to World. Adds a chosen structure from the player's structure file to the game file therefore making possible to load it in that world. Structures in the structure file can be accessed from the files section of the settings menu.

It's difficult to want to invest in this game when features that many people want, aren't implemented.  All I wanted to do was copy a 3D Grogu I made into my Daughter's World, which led me down this rabbit hole.  Having to put my android phone into Dev mode to copy out my "Application" world save data and copy back as "external" save data, only then to find out the Structure_Block only saves to the world's database and not actually to a file.  What a pain.   Having this functionality would actually make me want to get the Realm sub again.

https://bugs.mojang.com/browse/MCPE-49465 

"Thank you for your report!
However, this issue has been closed as Working as Intended.

Remember not all differences between game versions/platforms of Minecraft are bugs. Structure blocks in Bedrock have been implemented slightly differently, and the different save choices work as follows:

Currently in Bedrock, the Save to Disk option doesn't save the structure as a loose file like in Java. Instead it saves it on disk as part of leveldb (world data). It is different from save in memory though. With Save in Memory, the structure data is only available during that game session. If you choose save to disk instead, the structure data persists on disk and so will still be present on future gameplay sessions."

Actually we can do this by using the "Export" feature (not 3D export) of the structure block to create a .mcstructure file that can be manipulated in various ways, plus...

Currently we can move any saved .mcstructure files between worlds by creating a "structures" folder inside any active behavior pack folder for the target world (must be in the specific behavior pack folder for the specific target world). Then just copy your .mcstructure files into that "structures" folder. The moved structure files are then accessible in your target world by using the standard Structure Block "Load" function. It's tricky because you need to know how to navigate the Minecraft Bedrock Edition folders, but it works!
I completely agree with you on this and the sizes needs to be increased as well imo..

you can do this from a save mode structure block by hitting the export button and moving the resulting .mcstructure to a "structures" folder in a behavior pack and applying the pack to the world you want to move to, then load by using the save name of the structure in the pack in a load block. it sounds complicated but its really not. the reason that they use this system in bedrock instead of the java system is so that you can't export from marketplace worlds and plagiarize content.
